summary: CHIKV is a single-stranded RNA arthropod-borne virus belonging to the Alphavirus genus. it is transmitted to humans by mosquitoes from the Aedes genus. CHIKV rapidly expanded through the region causing outbreaks in the Antilles, Central and South America, and the united states. the CHIKV epidemic was at its peak in Puerto Rico from June 1, 2014 to September 30, 2014. all patients with laboratory-positive CHIKV infection from June 1, 2014 to September 30, 2014 were included in this study. self-reported clinical manifestations included chills, tiredness, arthralgia, joint swelling, back pain, myalgia, rash, ocular pain, abdominal pain, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dizziness, dyspnea, palpitations, and chest pain. Clinical manifestations associated with peripheral joint involvement. patients with acute CHIKV who had peripheral joint involvement were older than those without joint symptoms. other authors have described that pediatric patients with acute CHIKV are more likely to experience nonspecific symptoms such as fever rather than the typical clinical features such as arthralgia. a cross-sectional study evaluating patients with acute CHIKV infection from two rural villages in India reported myalgia in only 25% of the population. the presence of back pain during acute CHIKV infection has been infrequently reported in the literature and classically is more associated with dengue fever. only 39% were in the severe range and 40% had maculopapular rash. rash was present in 64% of confirmed cases in a recent epidemic in Colombia. ocular pain was present in nearly half of patients with confirmed acute CHIKV infection. rash and lymphopenia may mimic the acute onset of autoimmune connective tissue diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). CHIKV may mimic other rheumatic diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which shares some clinical and immunologic features. the presence of peripheral joint involvement was associated with other musculoskeletal symptoms such as myalgia and back pain. peripheral joint arthralgia/arthritis was not associated with female gender and chronic comorbid conditions.
